Another Nixon creation debuts, "All My Children," also with Nixon as head writer.
The soap opera "Loving" premieres. Nixon is co-creator with Douglas Marland.
Nixon becomes the first female writer to be inducted into the Soap Opera Hall of Fame.
The National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences announces Nixon as the recipient of the Lifetime Achievement Award.
ABC announces the cancellation of "One Life to Live" as of January 2012. "All My Children" is also being canceled.
ABC announces "All My Children" will air its final episode on television on Friday, September 23, 2011.
"One Life to Live" airs its final episode on television.
"One Life to Live" and "All My Children" come back to life, airing twice weekly online at Hulu and Apple's iTunes. Nixon is the creator of the new "All My Children."
Passes away at the age of 93.
Manuel Noriega: An expose of Noriega by Seymour Hersh appears in the New York Times, accusing him of murder, money laundering and drug trafficking.
The United States indicts Noriega on charges of racketeering, laundering drug money and drug smuggling.
The United States invades Panama and launches "Operation Just Cause" to oust Noriega.
Surrenders after 10 days spent in the Vatican's diplomatic mission in Panama City.
Is convicted on eight counts of drug smuggling and racketeering.
Is sentenced to 40 years in prison.
His US sentence is reduced to 30 years.

Judge William Hoeveler rules that Noriega can be extradited to France to serve a 10-year prison sentence for money laundering. Attorneys for Noriega argued that his status as a prisoner of war meant he should be sent back to Panama.
Noriega's scheduled mandatory release date from prison. However, due to appeals of his extradition to France, Noriega is not released.

The 11th US Circuit Court of Appeals hears arguments in Noriega's bid to avoid extradition to France. The court will later address whether his status as a Prisoner of War, under the rules of the Geneva Convention, means he must be repatriated to Panama.
The US Supreme Court refuses to hear Noriega's appeal.
Noriega is extradited to France after Secretary of State Hillary Clinton signs an extradition order.
Noriega is found guilty of money laundering in a French court and is sentenced to seven years in prison.

The French foreign ministry announces that it has begun the process of extraditing Noriega to Panama, with the consent of the United States. He is wanted in Panama on charges he killed a political rival.
A French appeals court approves Noriega's extradition to Panama to serve out his sentences for past crimes.
Noriega is extradited to Panama from France.
Noriega is hospitalized in Panama City for hypertension and a possible stroke.
Files a lawsuit against the Activision Blizzard video game company for harming his reputation with the game, "Call of Duty: Black Ops II."
A judge dismisses Noriega's lawsuit against the creators of the "Call of Duty" video game franchise.
Noriega apologizes, on local broadcaster Telemetro, to his country for the offenses of his regime and his own actions that led up to the 1989 US invasion and his ouster.
Noriega's doctor reports that the former Panamanian leader will need to undergo surgery to remove a benign brain tumor.
A Panama court rules that Noriega can prep for and recover from brain surgery at home under house arrest.
Undergoes surgery to remove the brain tumor. He suffers severe brain hemorrhaging and is placed in a medically induced coma.
Panama's President Juan Carlos Varela announces the death of Noriega.
Sandra Day O'Connor: Formally nominated to the Supreme Court by President Ronald Reagan, to fill the seat of retiring Justice Potter Stewart.
Sworn in as the first female Supreme Court justice of the United States.
Has surgery for breast cancer after being diagnosed earlier in the year.
Is awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Barack Obama.
Releases the book "Out Of Order," which is based on the Supreme Court and its history.
Writes a letter revealing that she has been diagnosed with the "beginning stages of dementia, probably Alzheimer's disease."
Ehud Olmert: Olmert is appointed Minister of Finance.
Is named Acting Prime Minister after Sharon suffers a stroke.
The Kadima party wins the largest number of parliamentary seats, ensuring that Olmert will be the next Prime Minister.
Is sworn in as the 12th Prime Minister of Israel.
Addresses a joint meeting of the US Congress.
Olmert announces he will resign as prime minister when Kadima elects a new chairman.
Tzipi Livni becomes the leader of the Kadima Party.
Resigns shortly after police recommend charges in corruption probes.
Is indicted on charges including fraud and breach of trust in dual scandals called the Talansky affair and the Rishon Tours affair. The trial begins in September 2009.

While on trial for fraud and breach of trust, Olmert is indicted for bribery in a separate case. The charge is related to three real estate projects, including a controversial housing development in Jerusalem called Holyland. The scandal becomes known as the Holyland affair.

Olmert's trial ends after almost three years. He is found guilty of breach of trust and acquitted on two corruption charges. He receives a one year suspended jail sentence and is ordered to pay a fine of 75,000 shekels (about $19,000).

Is convicted of bribery charges in a trial related to the Holyland Affair. Olmert is sentenced to six years in prison and fined 1 million shekels ($289,000). His sentence is later reduced to 18 months by the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court orders a retrial in the Rishon Tours/Talansky case, as new evidence emerges, enabling prosecutors to challenge Olmert's acquittals on corruption charges in 2012.
Olmert is convicted of fraud and breach of trust in the retrial of the Rishon Tours/Talansky case. His total prison sentence for the Talansky/Rishon Tours case and the Holyland Affair is 27 months.
Olmert is released after serving 16 months, two-thirds of his original 27-month prison term.
"Honorable Men," a documentary about Olmert, premieres at Tel Aviv's DocAviv documentary film festival.
Yoko Ono: Ono and John Lennon are arrested in London for possession of cannabis. In court the following month, Lennon admits possession and is fined £150. Ono's charges are dropped.
During their honeymoon, Ono and Lennon stage their first "bed-in" in their Amsterdam hotel room to promote world peace.
Ono and Lennon release "Plastic Ono Band" solo LPs on the same day.
Mark David Chapman, a deranged fan, shoots and kills Lennon in front of the Dakota hotel, where he and Ono live. Ono is a few feet away during the shooting.
Lennon and Ono's album, "Milk and Honey," is released.

Unveils the Imagine Peace Tower, an outdoor art installation that emits a ray of light every year from October 9th (John's birthday) until December 8th (the date of his death). The tower is also illuminated annually on New Year's Eve, Ono's birthday in February, and the start of the Vernal Equinox and Winter Solstice. The tower is located on Vioey Island in Reykjavik, Iceland.
Ono tells CNN's Anderson Cooper that she was blamed for the breakup of the Beatles because of racism and sexism.
Releases "Take Me to the Land of Hell" with Yoko Ono Plastic Ono Band.
Ono exhibits "Land of Hope," consisting of 19 pieces of her conceptual artwork in Mexico City's Memory and Tolerance Museum. The exhibit is interactive and promotes an anti-violence message.
The album, "Hell in Paradise 2016, Part 1," a collection of remixes featuring Ono, is released.
The album, "Hell in Paradise 2016, Part 2," is released.
The National Music Publishers Association announces that Ono will be added as a co-writer on John Lennon's 1971 song "Imagine."
The album, "Warzone," is released. The album contains reimagined versions of Ono's past works.
The documentary, "John & Yoko: Above Us Only Sky," is released.
On the 39th anniversary of Lennon's death, Ono posts a tribute to Lennon on Twitter, stating "The death of a loved one is a hollowing experience."
Rosa Parks: Parks is arrested for not giving up her seat on a public bus to a white man while on her way home from her job as a seamstress at the Montgomery Fair department store, thus violating Jim Crow practices.

Day one of the 381-day boycott of the Montgomery bus system in response to Parks' arrest and segregation in general.  It becomes known as the official beginning of the civil rights movement.  On the same day, Parks is tried and found guilty of violating Montgomery's segregation laws. Her attorneys appeal the verdict, arguing the laws are unconstitutional.
The U.S. Supreme Court declares Montgomery bus segregation laws unconstitutional and illegal.
The court's written order is officially served to Montgomery officials.  The boycott ends and buses are integrated.
Attends the State of the Union Address, sits with First Lady Hillary Clinton and is mentioned in the address with regards to the country's efforts to bring about racial harmony.
Is presented the Congressional Gold Medal by President Bill Clinton.
Parks' lawyer confirms that Parks has dementia.

Legal dispute surrounding the appointment of a guardian for Parks: A judge appoints former Detroit Mayor Dennis Archer the legal guardian of Parks, but Park's lawyer files a motion to block Archer's appointment.
A judge releases Parks' medical records showing that she has suffered from dementia since at least 2002, two years before the $5 billion lawsuit was filed in her name.

A settlement in the suit against Outkast and record and distribution companies is announced. OutKast and co-defendants will help develop educational programs and will work with the Rosa and Raymond Parks Institute to promote Parks' legacy.
Rosa Parks dies at the age of 92 of natural causes.
Sarah Palin: Is elected governor of Alaska, defeating former two-term governor Tony Knowles (49% to 41%).

Alaska state legislators vote to hire an investigator to determine if Palin fired former state Public Safety Commissioner Walt Monegan because he would not fire Palin's former brother-in-law, Mike Wooten, a state trooper.
A former state employee files an ethics complaint against Palin, accusing her of using her position to get a supporter a government position.
Named as Arizona Senator John McCain's vice presidential running mate.
Announces her 17-year-old daughter, Bristol, is five months pregnant, and the McCain campaign releases a statement that McCain knew about the pregnancy when he selected her as his running mate.
Accepts the Republican Party's nomination for vice president at the Republican National Convention.
State investigator Stephen Branchflower releases a report that Palin abused her power as Alaska's governor and violated state ethics law by trying to get her ex-brother-in-law fired.
Appears on "Saturday Night Live" with Palin lookalike Tina Fey.
Alaska's Personnel Board releases a report concluding that Palin did not violate ethics law in relation to her ex-brother-in-law.
McCain loses the presidential election to Barack Obama.
Launches political action committee SarahPAC to raise money.
Announces that she will be stepping down as governor of Alaska.
Steps down as governor of Alaska. Lt. Gov. Sean Parnell becomes governor.
Delivers the keynote address at the first national Tea Party convention.
Discovery Communications announces Palin will appear in an eight-part documentary series, called "Sarah Palin's Alaska," on the TLC network.
The state of Alaska releases roughly 24,000 pages of emails from Palin's governorship that had been requested in 2008 under the Freedom of Information Act.
Announces she is not running for president.

In a Facebook post on Martin Luther King Day, Palin sends a message to President Obama, "Mr. President, in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. and all who commit to ending any racial divide, no more playing the race card."
The subscription-based Sarah Palin Channel launches online.
Endorses Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump at an Iowa campaign stop.
Palin's husband, Todd, is seriously injured in a snow machine crash in Alaska and is in intensive care. He is hospitalized for two weeks.
Files a lawsuit against the New York Times alleging that a recent editorial falsely portrayed her as responsible for inciting the 2011 shooting of Democratic Rep. Gabby Giffords.
A federal judge dismisses Palin's defamation lawsuit against the New York Times, declaring that he sees no evidence of malicious intent.
A federal appeals court reverses a lower court's decision to dismiss Palin's defamation lawsuit, giving her another chance to square off with the New York Times.

Todd Palin files for divorce from Sarah Palin, after 31 years of marriage. The divorce filing and court records use only initials to refer to the pair, with Todd Mitchell Palin listed as TMP and Sarah Louise Palin only identified as SLP.
Leon Panetta: Head of the US Office for Civil Rights.
Nominated by President-elect Barack Obama to be the new director of the CIA.
Confirmed by the US Senate as the new director of the CIA.
President Obama nominates Panetta to be the new secretary of defense to replace Robert Gates.
Confirmed by the US Senate as the next secretary of defense.
Attends the handover ceremony in Baghdad, commemorating the end of Operation Iraqi Freedom.
Announces the US military will end its longstanding policy of excluding women from combat and open front-line units to female service members.
Publishes a memoir: "Worthy Fights: A Memoir of Leadership in War and Peace."

Joins 88 other former defense officials in Washington Post open letter criticizing President Donald Trump's threat to use the US active military to quell nationwide protests over the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man, at the hands of Minneapolis police.
Joe Paterno: Named head coach at Penn State.
Suffers a broken leg during a sideline collision.
Wins 409th career victory to surpass Grambling State coach Eddie Robinson as the winningest coach in NCAA Division I football.

A grand jury report is released containing testimony alleging that former Penn State University defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky sexually abused eight young boys over a period of at least 15 years. Officials at Penn State also purportedly failed to notify law enforcement after learning about some of these incidents.-- The grand jury report says graduate assistant Mike McQueary told Coach Paterno that he witnessed the rape of a 10-year-old boy by Jerry Sandusky on February 9, 2001 in the Lasch Building showers at Penn State. Paterno refers to the incident as "fondling" or "something of a sexual nature" in his testimony to the grand jury.-- Paterno reports the incident to Athletic Director Tim Curley the day after he is told by McQueary, according to a grand jury report, but no law enforcement investigation is launched.

Paterno announces that he intends to retire at the end of the 2011 football season. Hours later, university trustees announce he and university president Graham Spanier are fired, effective immediately. Paterno coached football at Penn State for 62 seasons, including 45 years as head coach.
In response to Paterno's firing, protesting Penn State students clash with police. The crowd tips over a news van and is later dispersed with tear gas.
The Penn State Nittany Lions lose to the Nebraska Cornhuskers, 17-14. It is the first game since Paterno's firing.
Scott Paterno announces that his father has a treatable form of lung cancer.
Paterno is admitted to a hospital with a re-fractured pelvis due to a fall in his home. He initially injured his pelvis in August during a preseason practice collision.
Is released from the hospital.
Dies of metastatic small cell carcinoma of the lung at Mount Nittany Medical Center in State College at the age of 85.
Former Penn State assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky is found guilty on 45 of 48 counts related to sexual abuse of boys over a 15-year period. He is later sentenced to 30 to 60 years in prison.

Former FBI Director Louis Freeh releases the findings of the investigation into Penn State's action concerning Sandusky and child abuse. The report accuses Paterno and other former leaders at Penn State of showing "total and consistent disregard" for child sex abuse victims, while covering up the attacks of a longtime sexual predator.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) rules that Penn State must vacate all wins from 1998-2011. Due to the vacated wins, Paterno is no longer the all-time winningest coach in NCAA Division I football history. Of his 409 wins, Paterno is stripped of 111, leaving him with 298.

The Paterno family and others file a lawsuit against the NCAA to invalidate sanctions handed down against Penn State in July 2012. Penn State was fined $60 million, stripped of 14 seasons of football victories and reduced scholarships. The NCAA later seeks to dismiss the suit.

The NCAA agrees to restore 112 of Penn State's wins111 of them with Joe Paterno. The agreement is part of a settlement reached between Pennsylvania state officials and Paterno's family, who filed a lawsuit against the NCAA. This resolution restores his status as the winningest coach in NCAA Division I football. The Paterno family releases a statement on the NCAA's decision that "a large measure of wrong has been righted."

A new allegation purports Paterno knew that his assistant coach Jerry Sandusky was sexually abusing a child as early as 1976, according to a new court filing in an ongoing lawsuit brought by Penn State against its former insurance company. This date is 12 years before what had been thought was the earliest known allegation of abuse by Sandusky.

CNN reports on another alleged victim who explained how he was a troubled young kid in 1971 when he was raped in a Penn State bathroom by Jerry Sandusky. Then, he says, his complaint about it was ignored by Paterno.
Newly unsealed court documents allege that Paterno knew about Sandusky's abuse and that he dismissed a victim's complaint.

Penn State announces that it has reached a "resolution of the outstanding issues" between the university and Paterno's family, eight years after a university report blamed Paterno and others for allegedly taking part in a cover-up to avoid bad publicity related to the Sandusky scandal.
Rand Paul: Announces on Fox News that he is running as a Republican for the US Senate to represent Kentucky.
Defeats Secretary of State Trey Grayson in the Kentucky GOP Senate primary.

In interviews with NPR and MSNBC, while answering questions about the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Paul expresses strong abhorrence for racism, but says that it is the job of communities, not the government, to address discrimination. Paul later releases a statement saying that he supports the Civil Rights Act and would not support its repeal.
Paul is elected to the Senate, defeating Jack Conway.
Sworn in for the 112th Congress. It is the first time a son joins the Senate while his father concurrently serves in the House. Ron Paul retires from the House in 2013.
Participates in the inaugural meeting of the Senate Tea Party Caucus with Senators Mike Lee and Jim DeMint.
Paul's book "The Tea Party Goes to Washington" is published.

Paul's book "Government Bullies: How Everyday Americans Are Being Harassed, Abused, and Imprisoned by the Feds" is published. He is later accused of plagiarism in some of his speeches and writings, including in "Government Bullies." Paul ultimately takes responsibility, saying his office had been "sloppy" and pledging to add footnotes to all of his future material.
Delivers the Tea Party response  to President Barack Obama's State of the Union address.
Paul speaks for almost 13 hours, filibustering to stall a confirmation vote on CIA Director nominee John Brennan.

Paul and the conservative group FreedomWorks file a class-action lawsuit against Obama and top national security officials over the government's electronic surveillance program made public by intelligence leaker Edward Snowden. The lawsuit is later dismissed.
Paul announces his bid for a second term in the Senate.
Paul announces his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination during an event in Louisville, Kentucky.

After 10 hours and 30 minutes, Paul ends his "filibuster" over National Security Agency surveillance programs authorized under the Patriot Act. Paul's speech wasn't technically a filibuster because of intricate Senate rules, but his office insists it was a filibuster.

The Justice Department indicts two officials from a Rand Paul Super PAC for conspiracy and falsifying campaign records. During the 2012 presidential primary season, Jesse Benton and John Tate allegedly bribed an Iowa state senator to get him to endorse Ron Paul. Benton and Tate go on to help run one of the Super PACs supporting Rand Paul, America's Liberty PAC. Both men are later convicted.
Announces that he is suspending his campaign for the presidency.
Wins a second term in the Senate, defeating Democrat Jim Gray.

A neighbor assaults Paul at his home in Bowling Green, Kentucky, which results in six broken ribs and a pleural effusiona build-up of fluid around the lungs. The attorney representing Paul's neighbor, Rene Boucher, later says that the occurrence had "absolutely nothing" to do with politics and was "a very regrettable dispute between two neighbors over a matter that most people would regard as trivial." Boucher, who pleaded guilty to the assault, is sentenced in June 2018 to 30 days in prison with a year of supervised release.
A jury awards him more than $580,000 in his lawsuit against the neighbor who attacked him in 2017. The amount includes punitive damages and payment for pain and suffering as well as medical damages.
Paul says part of his lung had to be removed by surgery following the 2017 attack by Boucher.
Paul announces that he has tested positive for the novel coronavirus, becoming the first US senator to test positive for coronavirus.
Ron Paul: Unsuccessfully runs for president of the United States as the Libertarian Party candidate.
Defeats Charles Morris and is elected to the US House of Representatives as a Republican for the 14th District of Texas.
Files a statement of candidacy with the Federal Elections Commission to run for president as a Republican, officially entering the race for the White House.
Announces his run for the presidency in Exeter, New Hampshire.
Paul announces he will not seek reelection for his Congressional seat in 2012.
Paul ends active campaigning for the presidency.
Retires from the US House of Representatives.
Launches his foreign policy think tank, the Ron Paul Institute for Peace and Prosperity.

Three of Paul's aides from the 2012 presidential campaign are indicted for conspiring to pay an Iowa state senator $73,000 to secure his endorsement before the state held its caucuses. The senator had previously supported Michele Bachmann. All three of the former aides are convicted in 2016.

Is hospitalized after an apparent medical episode but is "doing fine," according to a tweet posted to his Twitter account. Just prior to his hospitalization, Paul was seen visually slurring his words during a livestream on his YouTube channel. The video has since been removed.
Hank Paulson: Unanimously confirmed by the Senate as Treasury secretary.
Paulson's memoir "On the Brink: Inside the Race to Stop the Collapse of the Global Financial System" is released.
Senior fellow at the University of Chicago Harris School of Public Policy Studies.
Joe Berlinger's documentary about Paulson, "Hank: Five Years from the Brink," premieres on Netflix.
Paulson's book "Dealing with China" is published.
Tim Pawlenty: Speaks at the Republican National Convention.
Announces he will not run for a third term as governor.
Begins tour for book, "Courage to Stand: An American Story," traveling to key election states New Hampshire and Iowa.
Announces the formation of a presidential exploratory committee, via a Facebook video.

On CNN's "Piers Morgan Tonight" Pawlenty says, "I'm running for president. I'm not putting my hat in the ring rhetorically or ultimately for vice president. I'm focused on running for president." Pawlenty's campaign says the comments were not an official announcement.
Officially announces his candidacy for president, during a town hall-style meeting at the State of Iowa Historical Building in Des Moines.
Drops out of the presidential race.
Endorses Mitt Romney for president and joins Romney's campaign as national co-chair.

Pawlenty announces he is stepping down as national co-chairman of Mitt Romney's presidential campaign to take a job as president and CEO of the Financial Services Roundtable, a Washington-based lobbying group. His new role formally begins November 1.
In a video announcement, Pawlenty officially declares himself a candidate for Minnesota governor.
Loses in the Republican gubernatorial primary to Hennepin County Commissioner Jeff Johnson.
Pel\u00e9: Scores his first professional goal in his league debut, during a match between Santos FC and Corinthians Football Club.
Scores his 1,000th goal at his 909th first-class game.
Retires from playing with an exhibition game between the Cosmos and Santos FC. He plays the first half for the Cosmos and the second half for Santos.
Britain's Queen Elizabeth II awards him an honorary knighthood.
Undergoes surgery to remove kidney stones.

Is admitted to a Brazilian hospital with a urinary tract infection. On November 29, the hospital issues two statements saying that Pelé continues to improve and that doctors plan to take him off dialysis the next day.
The Brazilian football club Santos signs a lifetime contract with Pelé, making him its lifetime global ambassador.
Is hospitalized to undergo prostate surgery. He is released after two days.
It is announced that he will not light the Olympic cauldron in the opening ceremony of the 2016 summer games due to health problems.
Launches The Pelé Foundation, a charity that will team with other organizations to benefit children, specifically in the areas of poverty and education.
Is taken to a hospital in Paris because of a urinary tract infection.

Returns to Brazil and is admitted to the Albert Einstein Hospital in Sao Paolo for a urinary tract infection caused by kidney stones. Four days later, he has surgery. He leaves the hospital two days after surgery.
Nancy Pelosi: Wins a special election in California's 5th Congressional District, filling the seat of Representative Sala Burton.
Votes against authorizing use of force in Iraq (House Resolution 77).
Is elected House minority leader by fellow Democrats and becomes the highest-ranking woman in congressional history.

Democrats win a majority in the House. Pelosi becomes the speaker of the House when the new congress begins in January 2007. She is the first female speaker of the House and the first woman to be as high in the line of succession to the presidency (second behind the vice president).
Pelosi leads a bipartisan delegation from the House on a trip through the Middle East. The group travels to Israel, Lebanon, Syria, and Saudi Arabia, meeting with heads of state.
Is reelected with more than 70% of the vote.
Meets with Pope Benedict XVI.
Pelosi leads the House in passing the health care reform bill proposed by President Barack Obama.
In a 150-43 vote, Pelosi is elected to serve as minority leader in the 112th Congress.
Pelosi challenges John Boehner for speaker of the House but loses 220-192. She instead is reelected as House minority leader.
Is reelected with more than 82% of the vote.
Is reelected as House Democratic leader.

Is reelected as House minority leader, with four of her colleagues voting for someone else for the top Democratic post following a year that saw both parties questioning their congressional leadership.
VH1 announces that Pelosi will be a guest judge on season 3 of "RuPaul's Drag Race All Stars."

Pelosi sets the record for the longest speech on the House floor, according to the House Historian's records. She speaks continuously for a little more than eight hours to oppose the budget deal to lift spending caps and avert a government shutdown -- because the plan does not address immigration issues.
Donates her speaker's gavel, among other items, to the Smithsonian in honor of Women's History Month.
Is officially elected the new House speaker in a majority vote by the House of Representatives on the first day of the 116th Congress.

President Donald Trump declares his annual State of the Union address "canceled" after Pelosi sends word, she will bar him from delivering the speech in the House chamber while parts of the government remain shut down.
Pelosi announces the launch of a formal impeachment inquiry into Trump.
After Trump appears to ignore Pelosi's attempt at a handshake prior to his State of the Union address, she can be seen on camera stoically ripping up her copy of the speech once he concluded.
Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto: Wins the presidential election, with about 38% of the vote.
The electoral tribunal validates election results and officially names Peña Nieto as president-elect.
Travels to Washington and meets with US President Barack Obama.
Is sworn in as president of Mexico.

The Aristegui Noticias website publishes an investigative report that alleges Peña Nieto and his wife have been living in a $7 million mansion owned by a contractor who's won lucrative government projects. In a video, the First Lady says she has "nothing to hide," stating that she paid for the house with money she earned as an actress.
In response to the disappearance of 43 students, Peña Nieto proposes a series of reforms in order to help combat crime and corruption in Mexico.
Excelsior newspaper publishes an interview with Peña Nieto, in which he says Mexico will not pay for US presidential candidate Donald Trump's proposed border wall.

In an article published by Aristegui Noticias, scholars analyze Peña Nieto's college thesis and conclude that passages were plagiarized. Peña Nieto's office responds that he inadvertently left off attribution in spots.
Following a meeting with Trump, Peña Nieto tweets he told the presidential candidate that Mexico will not pay for the wall. Trump tells reporters they did not discuss payment for the wall.

Cancels a meeting with Trump amid renewed tensions over the border wall. The men later speak on the phone. The Washington Post publishes a leaked transcript of the call, in which Trump urges Peña Nieto to stop criticizing the wall proposal. Trump also reportedly refers to New Hampshire as a "drug-infested den" and claims, without evidence, that he won 84% of the Cuban-American vote.
Signs a decree that legalizes marijuana and cannabis derivatives for medicinal use nationwide.

Calls off an official trip to Washington, DC, to meet with Trump after a phone call in which Trump "would not agree to publicly affirm Mexico's position that it would not fund construction of a border wall," according to the Washington Post.
Posts a video of a speech on Twitter in response to Trump's rhetoric. Peña Nieto declares, "nothing and no one stands above the dignity of Mexico."

Trump, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, and Peña Nieto sign a replacement NAFTA deal during a ceremony at the G20 summit. The USMCA differs from the 1993 NAFTA in several ways, including notable changes to car and truck manufacturing.
Peña Nieto leaves office and is succeeded by Andrés Manuel López Obrador, known as AMLO.

Drug kingpin Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán once paid a $100 million bribe to Peña Nieto, according to testimony given by a former close personal aide to Guzman during his trial. Peña Nieto's former chief of staff denies the allegation.
Rivera announces she is divorcing Peña Nieto.
Shimon Peres: Awarded the Nobel Peace Prize along with Yasser Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin.
Wins the Israeli presidential election by a vote of 86-23 by the Knesset.
Takes office for a seven-year term.
Peres addresses the Turkish parliament, becoming the first Israeli president in history to speak to a Muslim country's legislature.
Urges peace talks with the Palestinians and warns the United Nations against recognizing Palestine as an independent state outside of a peace plan.
Receives the Presidential Medal of Freedom from US President Barack Obama during an East Room ceremony in the White House.

Releases a comedic YouTube video, "So Now What?" The video depicts the former president trying out a variety of new jobs including pizza deliveryman, gas station attendant, supermarket cashier and airport security guard. A mix of punchlines and life lessons, the video goes viral, with nearly 700,000 views.
During an exclusive interview with CNN, Peres expresses support of a nuclear deal with Iran and says it is feasible for inspectors to enforce the terms of the agreement.
Peres suffers a mild heart attack and undergoes surgery to insert a stent.

Lays the cornerstone for the Israeli Innovation Center at the Peres Peace House in Tel Aviv, together with President Reuven Rivlin and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The center aims to showcase Israel's technology achievements and encourage entrepreneurs and start-ups.
Peres is hospitalized after suffering a stroke.
Peres dies at the Sheba Medical Center in Tel Aviv after suffering a massive stroke two weeks prior.
Peres is buried at Mount Herzl, Israel's national cemetery.
Ross Perot: Founds Electronic Data Systems Corporation, (EDS), a data processing business, in Dallas with a $1,000 loan from his wife.
Sells EDS to General Motors Company (GM) for $2.5 billion and stock, becoming GM's single largest stockholder and a director.
Announces on CNN's "Larry King Live" that he will enter the presidential race if there are enough signatures to add him to the ballot in all 50 states.
Withdraws from the presidential race stating that he couldn't win and staying in the race would only create problems for the electoral process.
Qualifies for the Arizona ballot, completing efforts to put his name on all 50 state ballots.
Re-enters the presidential race as an independent.
Receives one of the largest percentages ever for an independent candidate in a presidential election (18.9%), but comes in third, behind Bill Clinton and incumbent President George H.W. Bush.
Receives 8% of the vote in the presidential election as the Reform Party candidate. President Clinton is re-elected to office.
President and CEO of Perot Systems Corporation.
Perot Systems Corporation gains 172% in its initial public offering.
Names his son, Ross Perot Jr., president and CEO of Perot Systems. The headquarters are moved to Plano, Texas, and Perot Sr., continues as chairman of the board until September 2004.
Dell Incorporated buys Perot Systems for $3.9 billion, a net gain of about $400 million for the Perot family.
The Perot Museum of Nature and Science opens in Dallas.
After a five-month battle with leukemia, Perot, 89, dies at his home in Dallas surrounded by his family.
Rick Perry: Perry is sworn in as governor after George W. Bush resigns to become president of the United States.
Perry is elected to a four-year term.
Is reelected governor.
Perry is elected for a third term in office.
Declares his candidacy for president during a speech in South Carolina.
Suspends his presidential campaign and endorses Newt Gingrich.
Announces that he will not run for reelection as Texas governor in 2014.

A grand jury indicts Perry on charges of coercion of a public servant and abuse of his official capacity. He allegedly threatened to veto funding for a statewide public integrity unit run by Travis County District Attorney Rosemary Lehmberg unless she resigned following her arrest on a drunk driving charge. She stayed in office, and he later vetoed the funding.

Perry voluntarily appears at the Travis County Court house to be booked and fingerprinted and to have his mug shot taken. He pleads not guilty to charges of coercion of a public servant and abuse of official capacity. The next day he makes the first of six campaign style stops across New Hampshire.
A state district judge in Texas denies a defense motion to have two felony charges dismissed against Perry.
Delivers his farewell address as governor.
Announces he is running for president at a rally in Addison, Texas.

A Texas appeals court dismisses one of two criminal charges against Perry. The court agrees with the argument from Perry's legal team that a Texas law concerning "coercion of a public servant" violates Perry's First Amendment freedom of speech rights. The court is allowing a charge related to abuse of power to move forward.
Suspends his campaign for the presidency.
Perry endorses Ted Cruz.
The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals drops charges against Perry alleging he abused his power while in office.
Perry is revealed as one of the members of the upcoming 23rd season of reality television dance competition "Dancing with the Stars" on ABC.
Is eliminated from "Dancing With The Stars."
Returns to "Dancing With The Stars" for the season finale. Perry dances with Vanilla Ice during a live performance of "Ice Ice Baby."
President-elect Donald Trump announces he has selected Perry to be his nominee for energy secretary.
Perry says that he regrets recommending the elimination of the Department of Energy during a presidential debate in 2012.
Perry is confirmed as energy secretary with a 62-37 vote in the Senate.

Perry's office acknowledges that he was the target of a prank call on July 19. During the 20-minute call from Russian pranksters, real names Vladimir Krasnov and Aleksey Stolyarov, respectively, one pretends to be Ukrainian Prime Minister Volodymyr Groysman.

Is named the designated survivor for Trump's second State of the Union address. As the one member of the Cabinet remaining outside the House chamber during the speech in case disaster strikes, Perry will remain in an undisclosed location.
House Democrats issue a subpoena to Perry for documents related to the Trump administration's contacts with Ukraine as part of the ongoing House impeachment inquiry.
Perry says he plans to resign in a video posted to YouTube.

Ambassador to the EU Gordon Sondland testifies that he, along with special envoy for Ukraine Kurt Volker and Perry, worked with Giuliani on Ukraine at the "express direction" of Trump and against their better judgment. Sondland also tells lawmakers that he had discussed the investigation in a July 19 email sent to several top US officials, including Perry. In response, the Department of Energy releases a statement denying Sondland's claims, saying he "misrepresented both Secretary Perry's interaction with Rudy Giuliani and direction the Secretary received from President Trump."
Perry resigns as US Secretary of Energy.
Perry is appointed as a director of the general partner that controls Energy Transfer LP, a pipeline company.
David Petraeus: Commander of the Multinational Security Transition Command in Iraq.
Commander of all coalition forces in Iraq.
Announces that he was diagnosed in February with early stage prostate cancer and underwent two months of radiation treatment.
Becomes "a little lightheaded" and faints while testifying at a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing.
Nominated by President Barack Obama to replace Leon Panetta as CIA director.
Unanimously confirmed by the US Senate as the next director of the CIA.
Petraeus turns over command of US and NATO forces in Afghanistan to Gen. John R. Allen.
Retires from the Army.
Petraeus is sworn in as the new director of the CIA.
Petraeus submits his resignation to President Obama, citing personal reasons and admits he had an extramarital affair.
Publicly apologizes for his extramarital affair during a speech at the University of Southern California.
It is announced that Petraeus has joined private equity firm KKR as the chairman of a new global institute.

Joins the University of Southern California faculty as a Judge Widney Professor, "a title reserved for eminent individuals from the arts, sciences, professions, business, and community and national leadership."

A federal law enforcement official tells CNN that Justice Department prosecutors are recommending charges be filed against Petraeus for disclosure of classified information to his former lover Paula Broadwell who was working on a book with Petraeus at the time.

Pleads guilty to one federal charge of removing and retaining classified information as part of a plea deal. According to court documents, Petraeus admitted removing several so-called black books -- notebooks in which he kept classified and non-classified information from his tenure as the commander of the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan -- and giving them to Broadwell.
White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest confirms that the National Security Council and the Obama administration have consulted with Petraeus on matters related to Iraq and ISIS.

Petraeus is sentenced to serve two years on probation and to pay a $100,000 fine for sharing classified information with his biographer and lover, Broadwell. Prosecutors agree to not send him to jail because the classified information was never released to the public or published in the biography.

Petraeus speaks before the Senate Armed Services Committee regarding the US's Middle East policy. He begins this, his first public hearing since his resignation, with a formal apology for the indiscretions that led to his resignation.
Along with retired NASA astronaut Mark Kelly, announces that they are launching Veterans Coalition for Common Sense to encourage elected leaders to "do more to prevent gun tragedies."
The University of Birmingham announces that Petraeus has accepted an honorary professorship in the Institute for Conflict, Cooperation and Security (ICCS). The three-year position begins immediately.
Regis Philbin: Philbin announces on-air that he's quitting "The Joey Bishop Show," and walks off stage, much to the surprise of Bishop and the crew. Differences are worked out and he rejoins the show four days later.
The title is shortened to "Live with Regis!" after Gifford's departure.
Kelly Ripa debuts as Regis' co-host on "Live! with Regis and Kelly."
Gets a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame at 6834 Hollywood Blvd.
Wins a Daytime Emmy for Outstanding Special Class Special for the "Walt Disney World Christmas Day Parade."
Is inducted into the National Association of Broadcasters Hall of Fame.
Wins the Daytime Emmy for Outstanding Special Class Special for "Walt Disney World Christmas Day Parade" and is also awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award.
During his show announces that 2011 will be his last year on "Live! with Regis and Kelly."
Shares a Daytime Emmy award win for Best Talk Show Host with co-host Ripa. They tie with Dr. Mehmet Oz for "The Oz Show."
Philbin's last show on "Live! with Regis and Kelly."
Wins a Daytime Emmy award for Best Talk Show Host with co-host Ripa.
Premiere of "Crowd Goes Wild," Philbin's new show on the network Fox Sports 1.
Philbin dies at age 88, according to a statement shared to CNN by his family.
Prince Philip: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth announce Elizabeth's engagement to Philip.
Is invested as a Knight of the Order of the Garter and is given the titles of Duke of Edinburgh, Earl of Merioneth and Baron Greenwich.
Marries Princess Elizabeth at Westminster Abbey. His name changes from Lt. Philip Mountbatten to His Royal Highness Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.
Philip and the Queen are the only senior members of the royal family who do not attend Charles and Camilla Parker-Bowles' civil wedding ceremony. They do attend the dedication service.
His 58th wedding anniversary makes him the longest-serving British consort, outliving the wife of King George III, Queen Charlotte.
Inspects British forces in southern Iraq.

Philip and the Queen visit the United States for the 400th anniversary of America's first British settlement in Jamestown in 1607. They attend the Kentucky Derby on May 5 and a state dinner at the White House on May 7.
Along with the Queen, meets US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama at Buckingham Palace.
His 90th birthday makes him the oldest-serving royal consort.
Undergoes treatment for a blocked coronary artery at Papworth Hospital.
Is hospitalized for a bladder infection at King Edward VII Hospital in London. He misses part of the Jubilee celebrations commemorating the Queen's 60th anniversary on the throne.
Is treated at Aberdeen Royal Infirmary for a bladder infection.
Is a patient in London Clinic, admitted for abdominal pain, he has exploratory surgery the following day and is released following his recuperation.
Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott awards that nation's top honor, Knight of the Order of Australia, to Philip for his life of service throughout the Queen's reign.
Buckingham Palace announces that Philip will step down from public life after August 2017.
Attends a parade of the Royal Marines at Buckingham Palace, carrying out the last of his thousands of public appearances before stepping back from public life.
Philip is admitted to a London hospital to undergo planned surgery on his hip.

Is involved in a traffic accident when his car collides with another vehicle carrying two women, aged 28 and 45, as well as a nine-month-old baby boy. In a statement the following day, a spokesperson said the Duke of Edinburgh had a "precautionary check-up" on doctor's advice that confirmed Philip "had no injuries of concern." It is later announced that he will not face any charges over the accident.
Buckingham Palace announces that Philip has surrendered his driving license following his January traffic accident that left a female driver injured.
Philip is admitted to the hospital over a "pre-existing" condition, according to a statement from Buckingham Palace. He leaves the hospital on December 24.
Philip makes a rare public statement thanking those working across the UK to help tackle the coronavirus pandemic.
Oscar Pistorius: Sustains knee injury while playing rugby in high school.

International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) introduces rule 144.2, which prohibits: (e) Use of any technical device that incorporates springs, wheels or any other element that provides the user with an advantage over another athlete not using such a device.
In Rome, finishes second in the 400m 'B' race against able-bodied athletes. The race is an IAAF test to observe and determine if rule 144.2 is being broken. The results are inconclusive.

Completes a series of tests in Cologne, Germany, to evaluate the metabolic differences in amputees and non-amputees and whether or not those differences caused by use of the Flex-Foot Cheetah prosthetics violate rule 144.2. The report claims that the prosthetics give Pistorius an advantage over able-bodied competitors, which Pistorius strongly rejects.

Pistorius is banned from competing in all IAAF-sanctioned events, "...running with these prostheses requires a less-important vertical movement associated with a lesser mechanical effort to raise the body, and the energy loss resulting from the use of these prostheses is significantly lower than that resulting from a human ankle joint at a maximal sprint speed." The ruling is based on the evaluation done in Germany in November 2007.
An appeal to the ban is filed with the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) by Pistorius through the law firm of Dewey & LeBoeuf.
The CAS reverses the January IAAF ban on Pistorius and the Cheetahs, making him eligible to compete in the Beijing Olympics.
Sustains major head and facial injuries in a boat accident on the Vaal River near Johannesburg.

Becomes the first double-amputee runner to compete in the Olympics, coming in eighth place in the 400m semifinal. Pistorius also later runs the anchor leg of the 4x400m relay final in which the South African team comes in eighth place.
Pistorius's girlfriend, South African model Reeva Steenkamp, is found shot to death at Pistorius' Pretoria, South Africa, home. Pistorius is arrested.
Pistorius is officially charged with premeditated murder in the death of Steenkamp.
Nike suspends their endorsement deal with Pistorius.

Leaves jail after posting a cash bond of 100,000 rand (about $11,200). Another 900,000 rand (about $100,800) is due by March 1. The conditions of Pistorius's bail are that he must avoid his home where the shooting occurred, relinquish his passport and abstain from drinking alcohol.

Judge Bert Bam lifts the travel ban on Pistorius, saying he sees no reason Pistorius should not be allowed to travel for competition. The ban on drinking alcohol and avoiding his home where the shooting occurred  is also lifted.
Is indicted on a premeditated murder charge in the shooting death of Steenkamp.
The murder trial begins with Pistorius pleading not guilty to one charge of murder and a firearms charge associated with Steenkamp's killing, as well as two gun indictments unrelated to Steenkamp.

The judge rules that Pistorius must undergo mental health examinations over the next month. The testing was triggered by the testimony of a psychiatrist who said that the sprinter has suffered from generalized anxiety disorder since he was an infant, stemming partly from the amputation of both of his lower legs.
A psychiatric assessment finds that Pistorius was not mentally incapacitated when he shot Steenkamp to death.
Is found guilty of culpable homicide, the South African term for unintentionally -- but unlawfully -- killing a person.
Receives a five-year sentence in the shooting death of Steenkamp.
South Africa's Department of Correctional Services tells CNN that a parole board is set to recommend that Pistorius be released from prison and transferred to house arrest in August.
A parole review board opts to "set aside the decision" and refers Pistorius' case "back to the (broader Correctional Supervision and Parole Board) for reconsideration."
In a statement, the parole board says it has approved Pistorius' placement under house arrest and correctional supervision for four years.
Is released from prison and placed under house arrest, according to Correctional Services spokesman Manelisi Wolela.
Pistorius' conviction for "culpable homicide" is changed to murder. Judge Eric Leach overturns the previous conviction, saying the original ruling was flawed.
Is granted bail. Pistorius will be able to leave his uncle's home, where he has been under house confinement, and can travel up to 20 kilometers (12 miles) between the hours of 7 a.m. and noon.
A South African judge sentences Pistorius to six years in prison for Steenkamp's murder. Barring an appeal, this will be the final sentencing.
State prosecutors ask to appeal the sentencing, telling the Supreme Court of Appeal that a six-year prison term is too lenient.
The Supreme Court of Appeal increases Pistorius' sentence to 13 years and five months for the murder of Steenkamp.
Pistorius loses his final appeal on the 13-year prison sentence.
Sidney Poitier: One of many Hollywood celebrities in attendance at the March on Washington.
Keynote speaker at the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in Atlanta.
Wins the Grammy Award for Best Spoken Word Album for "The Measure Of A Man."
Awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Barack Obama.
His sci-fi book, "Montaro Caine" is published.
Poitier receives the British Academy of Film and Television Arts Fellowship, its highest honor.
Colin Powell: National security adviser to President Ronald Reagan.
Gives the keynote address at the Republican National Convention in support of George W. Bush.
Is sworn in as the 65th secretary of state of the United States.
Powell addresses the United Nations Security Council to present the United States' case against Iraq under UN Resolution 1441 regarding weapons of mass destruction.
Undergoes surgery for prostate cancer at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was diagnosed with the disease in late summer 2003.
The White House announces President Bush has accepted Powell's letter of resignation dated November 12. The letter states he will remain in office until his successor is confirmed.
Resignation becomes effective with the confirmation of Condoleezza Rice.
Is one of the honorary co-chairs of President Barack Obama's inauguration. Powell endorsed Obama during the 2008 presidential campaign.
Powell reverses his stance on gays and lesbians in the military; his opposition to homosexuals in the military helped lead to the original "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy of the 1990s.
Powell, along with former secretaries of state Hillary Clinton and Madeleine Albright makes a cameo appearance on the CBS show "Madam Secretary."
Along with his wife Alma, Powell receives the Lincoln Medal, an award given by Ford's Theatre Society. The society celebrates those who embody the legacy of President Abraham Lincoln.
Elvis Presley: First movie, "Love Me Tender," is released.
"Flaming Star" is released, Elvis' only non-singing movie role.
Wins a Grammy in the gospel genre for Best Sacred Performance for "How Great Thou Art."
The television special "Elvis" airs. It is later called "The '68 Comeback Special."
Meets with US President Richard Nixon at the White House.
Wins a Grammy in the gospel genre for Best Inspirational Performance for "He Touched Me."
Elvis' television special, "Elvis: Aloha from HawaiiVia Satellite," is seen in 40 countries by 1 billion to 1.5 billion people.
Wins a Grammy in the gospel genre for Best Inspirational Performance (Non-Classical) for "How Great Thou Art."
Performs his last concert, in Indianapolis.
The US Postal Service releases an Elvis commemorative postage stamp. More than 500 million are printed, three times the usual print run for a commemorative stamp.
First annual Elvis Week. Tens of thousands attend the festivities at Graceland celebrating the 30th anniversary of his death.

US President Donald Trump posthumously awards Elvis the Presidential Medal of Freedom -- the nation's highest civilian honor -- along with six others, including baseball phenom Babe Ruth and Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia.
Forbes names Elvis number two on its top-earning dead celebrities list, with an estimated $39 million in earnings.
Vladimir Putin: Yeltsin appoints Putin as prime minister.
Yeltsin steps down amid scandal and Putin becomes acting president. He grants Yeltsin immunity from prosecution.
Is elected president of Russia.
Putin is sworn in.
Putin meets with US President George W. Bush and the men hold a joint press conference. Bush tells reporters that during the two-hour meeting, he was able to get a sense of Putin's soul.
Putin and Bush sign the Moscow Treaty on Strategic Offensive Reductions, which requires each country to reduce its stockpiles of strategic nuclear warheads over the course of ten years.
Is reelected after campaigning as an independent.
Putin is sworn in for his second term.
Becomes the first Russian leader to visit Israel.
Visits British Prime Minister Tony Blair and announces increased cooperation between Russia and Britain to fight terrorism.
Meets South African President Thabo Mbeki during the first visit to sub-Sarahan Africa by a Russian leader.
Named Time magazine's Person of the Year.
Dmitry Medvedev is elected president of Russia.
Just two hours after his presidential swearing in, Medvedev names Putin as prime minister.

Medvedev calls on the ruling United Russia party to endorse Putin for president in 2012. Putin in turn suggests that Medvedev should take over the role of prime minister if the party wins parliamentary elections in December.
Putin wins a third term as president, with just under 65% of the vote. Critics question the results amid complaints of voter fraud.
Putin is sworn in under tight security. Hundreds of protestors are detained by police.

US President Barack Obama signs the Magnitsky Act, a law that imposes travel and financial restrictions on individuals in Russia suspected of human rights violations. The law is named for Sergey Magnitsky, a lawyer who died under mysterious circumstances in 2009 after finding evidence that Russian officials committed tax fraud.
In response to the Magnitsky act, Putin signs into law a bill that effectively bans US citizens from adopting Russian children. The law also bans US-funded civic groups from operating in Russia.
During an interview broadcast on state-run television, Putin and his wife, Lyudmila, announce that their marriage is over.
Putin publishes an op-ed in the New York Times about the Syrian Civil War.
Putin signs a decree that bans food and agricultural imports from countries that have imposed sanctions against Russia.

Putin attends the United Nations General Assembly in New York and later meets with Obama. The two leaders discuss Ukraine and Syria, according to senior US officials. It is their first in-person meeting since Russia's incursion into Ukraine.
A UK inquiry is released, laying out evidence that suggests Putin approved the operation to kill former FSB spy Alexander Litvinenko in 2006.

The FBI announces it has launched an investigation into the hacking of the Democratic National Committee's computer system. Although the statement doesn't indicate that the agency has a particular suspect or suspects in mind, US officials tell CNN they think the cyberattack is linked to Russia.
During a Bloomberg News interview, Putin denies that the Russian government had any involvement in the hacking of Democratic National Committee emails.

Putin says that Russia will not expel American diplomats in response to the Obama administration's new sanctions and expulsion of 35 diplomats from the United States. He says he will instead try to rebuild relations with the incoming administration of US President-elect Donald Trump.

The US Office of the Director of National Intelligence releases a declassified report concluding that Putin ordered an "influence campaign" aimed at hurting Hillary Clinton and helping Trump in the 2016 presidential election.
At a news conference, Putin says that a damning dossier about Trump is "false" and he dismisses allegations that his country's security services have been monitoring the US president-elect.

Meets Trump for the first time on the sidelines of the G20 summit in Hamburg, Germany. During a two-hour meeting, the men reportedly discuss allegations of Russian meddling in the US election and the war in Syria, among other things. Hours later, they talk again informally during a dinner with other heads of state.

Putin announces that Russia is implementing a series of measures in response to a new sanctions bill approved by Trump. He says that 755 staffers at US diplomatic missions in Russia will be ousted from their jobs.

During his annual address to Parliament, Putin boasts about the country's nuclear capabilities, declaring that Russian missiles can elude air defense systems. In a video simulation, nuclear warheads are shown flying through space and raining down on a peninsula that resembles the state of Florida.

Putin wins the election, with 76.7% of the vote, according to Russia's Central Election Commission. His most prominent challenger, opposition leader Alexei Navalny was barred from running. International election monitors say that the votes were tallied in an orderly manner but they criticize the state-run media coverage of the presidential race, which heavily promoted Putin.
Is sworn in as president for another six years.

Putin and Trump meet in Helsinki and hold a joint news conference. Trump declines to endorse the US government's assessment that Russia interfered in the election. "I have great confidence in my intelligence people but I will tell you that President Putin was extremely strong and powerful in his denial today," Trump says.

Authorities in the United Kingdom assess that Putin approved a nerve agent attack on a former Russian spy. The attack in Salisbury, England sickened Sergei Skripal and his daughter, Yulia. One other woman who came into contact with the poison died.
North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un meets with Putin in Vladivostok. The summit includes one-on-one talks, but it does not include any signed agreements or joint statements.

Putin meets with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who says that he hopes the United States and Russia can develop a more cooperative relationship. Pompeo says he wants the countries to work together "to make our two peoples more, and frankly the world, more successful too."
Putin signs a law suspending Russia's participation in the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty.

Putin meets with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Sochi and the men announce a wide-ranging agreement on Syria, announcing that Russian and Turkish troops will patrol the Turkish-Syrian border. Kurdish forces have about six days to retreat about 20 miles away from the border.

Putin announces plans to push through reforms that would make his successor as president less powerful. Authority would be redistributed giving the Russian parliament and office of prime minister greater clout. The entire government resigns the same day.
Russians vote in favor of a nationwide referendum on constitutional changes. This paves the way for Putin to seek two more six-year terms when his presidency ends in 2024.
Ahmed Qorei: Qorei is awarded the Royal Norwegian Order of Merit, for his part in the Oslo Peace Accords.
Qorei is named economy minister of the first Palestinian cabinet.
Qorei resigns as economy minister in a feud with Yasser Arafat, but later resumes his duties.
The Palestinian Legislative Council is established, with Qorei as the Speaker.
Qorei is re-elected Speaker of the Council.
Qorei is elected to another term as Speaker of the Council.
At a roadblock south of Ramallah, Israeli soldiers accidentally fire upon Qorei's car, but he is uninjured.
Secretary of State Colin Powell meets with Qorei in Jericho and discusses the peace process.
Qorei is nominated by Arafat to replace Mahmoud Abbas, who was the first prime minister of the Palestinian Authority and resigned on September 6.
Qorei says he accepts the nomination to become Palestinian prime minister and help bring an end to the escalating violence between Israel and Palestinians.

Arafat declares a state of emergency in the Palestinian territories. This allows him to install a new Palestinian government by decree. He appoints Qorei as prime minister and names eight other people to an emergency cabinet.
Qorei is sworn in as Palestinian prime minister-designate of Arafat's emergency cabinet.
Arafat extends the term of his emergency cabinet. Qorei announces he will form a new government within a week.

The Palestinian Legislative Council approves the new 24-minister Cabinet presented by Qorei. Before the vote, Arafat addresses the council, saying he recognizes the state of Israel and its "right to live peacefully" alongside an independent Palestinian state.
Qorei resigns as prime minister, but Arafat urges Qorei to stay in his post.
Qorei says his written resignation -- filed over the growing chaos and violence in Gaza -- still stands.
In a news conference, Qorei announces that he has agreed to withdraw his resignation. Arafat agrees to turn over internal security to Qorei.
Following the death of Arafat, Qorei is named to replace him on the Palestinian National Security Council.
Qorei resigns as prime minister as his party, Fatah, is defeated by Hamas in the parliamentary elections.
His book, "From Oslo to Jerusalem: The Palestinian Story of the Secret Negotiations," is published.
His book, "Beyond Oslo, the Struggle for Palestine: Inside the Middle East Peace Process from Rabin's Death to Camp David," is published.
Qorei loses his seat on Fatah's Central Committee, the party's highest decision-making body.
His book, "Peace Negotiations in Palestine: From the Second Intifada to the Roadmap," is published.
Charles Rangel: Is elected to the House of Representatives to represent New York's 18th District.
Rangel's book, "And I Haven't Had a Bad Day Since: From the Streets of Harlem to the Halls of Congress," is published.
Rangel's lawyer, Lanny Davis, announces that Rangel unknowingly failed to report approximately $75,000 in income from a beach house he owns in the Dominican Republic.
The House Ethics Committee announces it is establishing an ethics panel to investigate Rangel.
Re-elected to a 20th term, serving New York's 15th District.
Rangel is admonished by the House Ethics Committee for accepting trips to the Caribbean that were paid for by corporate interests and is ordered to repay the money.
Announces he is stepping down as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee until an ethics investigation is complete.
The House Ethics Committee finds that Rangel violated ethics rules.

The House Ethics Committee formally charges Rangel with 13 counts of violating house rules in soliciting funds for a project, not disclosing financial papers, not paying taxes on a home in the Dominican Republic and improper use of a rent-subsidized apartment.
Wins re-election with 80 percent of the vote.
Rangel walks out of the House Ethics trial. The ethics panel wraps up its case.
A House Ethics subcommittee finds Rangel guilty on 11 charges against him.
The House votes to censure Rangel.

Rangel and his campaign agree to pay a $23,000 civil penalty in a settlement over the use of a rent-stabilized apartment as his campaign headquarters, according to Federal Election Commission documents.
Returns to Capitol Hill for the first time since February 9, after recovering from a back injury and viral infection.
Claims apparent victory in the Democratic primary with 45% of the vote, compared with New York State Sen. Adriano Espaillat, who received about 40 percent in the latest count.

Ballot issues arise after the June 26 primary and new unofficial numbers released by the New York City Board of Elections show Rangel ahead of New York State Sen. Espaillat by only two percentage points, 44% to 42%, with just 802 votes separating them and more than 3,000 votes unaccounted for.
At the end of the ballot count, the New York City Board of Elections announces that Rangel received 18,940 votes in the June 26 primary, beating state Sen. Espaillat who received 17,950 votes.
Is re-elected to a 22nd term with 91% of the vote. As a result of redistricting, Rangel will represent the new 13th District, which stretches from East Harlem to the northwest Bronx.
Is re-elected to a 23rd term with 87% of the vote.
Confirms that he will retire from Congress in January 2017.
Dan Rather: Attacked by security personnel as he attempts to question a Georgia delegate being removed from the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.
Is assaulted in New York by two men who he says repeatedly asked him, "Kenneth, what is the frequency?"
Walks off the "CBS Evening News" set in Miami to call CBS executives to protest a delayed starting time due to coverage of the US Open Tennis semi-finals. His actions cause six minutes of dead air.

Rather has a confrontational interview with Vice President George H. W. Bush over the Iran-Contra scandal. From that point on, Bush refuses to be interviewed by Rather. President George W. Bush also refuses to be interviewed by Rather.
Rather comes under fire after running a "60 Minutes II" story which alleges President George W. Bush received preferential treatment while serving in the Texas Air National Guard during the 1970s.
Rather apologizes and announces that he no longer has confidence in the authenticity of the documents used in the story about President Bush.
Formally steps down as the anchor of the "CBS Evening News."
Rather leaves CBS News, before his November contract expiration, ending a 44-year career with the network.
Makes debut as host of "Dan Rather Reports" on HDNet.

Files a $70 million lawsuit against CBS and Viacom, claiming he was made a scapegoat when the network came under criticism over the story about President Bush's service in the Texas Air National Guard.
Rather's lawsuit against CBS is dismissed.
Rather's request to reinstate his 2007 breach-of-contract lawsuit against CBS is rejected by New York's Court of Appeals.
Rather releases a memoir called "Rather Outspoken: My Life in the News."
The film, "Truth," based on the controversy surrounding Rather and his eventual departure from CBS, opens.
Debuts a weekly show, "Dan Rather's America," on SiriusXM.
Debuts a new show, "The News with Dan Rather," on The Young Turks Network.
Nancy Reagan: Signs a seven-year contract with MGM Studios.
Becomes the first lady of California when husband Ronald Reagan is sworn in as Governor.
Becomes the first lady of the United States when Ronald Reagan is sworn in as the 40th president.
Attends a Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation event and gives a speech advocating for embryonic stem cell research.
Unveils a statue of President Ronald Reagan in the Capitol Rotunda.

Reagan announces that the Reagan Foundation will partner and host the GOP presidential candidates debate in 2015 with CNN. Nancy Reagan believes that her husband "..announced his candidacy for the U.S. presidency because the citizens of this country wanted a president who could inspire...and it is time to find a new leader."
Reagan dies at her home in Los Angeles of congestive heart failure.
Ronald Reagan: Is elected president of the United States.
Is sworn in as president of the United States.
Is shot during an assassination attempt.
Undergoes surgery to remove a cancerous growth from his colon.
Is awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
Announces that he has Alzheimer's disease.
President and Mrs. Reagan are awarded the Congressional Gold Medal.
Is interred at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, in Simi Valley, California.
Vanessa Redgrave: Redgrave and her sister Lynn, lose the Best Actress Oscar to Elizabeth Taylor for "Whose Afraid of Virginia Wolfe?" Vanessa's nomination is for "Morgan: A Suitable Case for Treatment" and Lynn's is for "Georgy Girl."
Is made a Commander of the British Empire (CBE) by Queen Elizabeth II.

Wins Best Supporting Actress Academy Award for "Julia." Her acceptance speech is booed as she airs her political agenda and makes reference to "Zionist hoodlums" and her stance against anti-Semitism and fascism.
Wins Emmy for Best Actress Limited Series or a Special for "Playing for Time."
Wins Emmy for Best Supporting Actress in a Miniseries or Movie for "If These Walls Could Talk 2."
Wins the Tony for Best Actress Award for "Long Day's Journey into Night."
The first 10 episodes of the television program "Nip/Tuck" airs with Vanessa and her daughter Joely Richardson playing mother and daughter.
Redgrave's daughter, actress Natasha Richardson, dies from injuries in a skiing accident.
Is presented with the Academy Fellowship at the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) awards by Prince William.
Appears on British television in "The Call Out," an episode of "Playhouse Presents" written and directed by son Carlo Nero.
"Sea Sorrow," a documentary about the refugee crisis that marks Redgrave's directorial debut, premieres in a special screening at the Cannes Film Festival.
"The Aspern Papers" debuts at the Venice Film Festival starring Redgrave and her daughter, Joely Richardson.
The play,"Vienna 1934-Munich 1938," opens as a work in progress at London's Rose Theatre Kingston, starring Redgrave and her granddaughter, Daisy Bevan.
Stars in the movie "Mrs. Lowry & Son."
Sumner Redstone: Suffers third-degree burns over 40% of his body in a hotel fire in Boston. He survives by climbing out a window on to a ledge and hanging on until firefighters rescue him.
Redstone wins in a bidding war with QVC Network for Paramount Communications, parent company of Paramount Studios.
Becomes chief executive officer of Viacom, Inc.

Brent Redstone sues his father, accusing him of favoring daughter Shari Redstone in business matters. Redstone eventually buys out his son's stake in National Amusements, Inc., as part of a settlement.
Receives a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.
Paramount renames its administration building to Sumner Redstone Building as part of the studio's 100th anniversary celebration.
Steps down as executive chairman of CBS, and is replaced by Les Moonves, the network's chief executive.
Viacom CEO Philippe Dauman is named as Redstone's replacement as executive chairman of Viacom.

A trial to decide Redstone's mental competency opens in Los Angeles County Superior Court. Manuela Herzer, his ex-girlfriend, claims he was not of sound mind when he booted her from his mansion and signed an order revoking her authority over his healthcare decisions.
The challenge to Redstone's mental competency is dismissed by Los Angeles judge David J. Cowan. Redstone tells the judge that he wants his daughter Shari as his healthcare advocate.

Viacom announces a settlement with the Redstone family, National Amusements Inc., and others that terminates ongoing lawsuits in the tug-of-war over the company's future. Dauman's resignation is also announced. Redstone remains chairman emeritus.
Redstone sues former girlfriends Herzer and Sydney Holland and others in Los Angeles Superior Court. Charges include elder financial abuse, fraud, distress and not acting in his best interest.
Los Angeles County Superior Court Judge Cowan rules that Redstone is incapacitated because of a speech impediment. A guardian is appointed to protect his legal interests.
It is reported that lawsuits involving former girlfriend Herzer are settled before trial. She will pay $3.25 million to reimburse Redstone for gifts given to her during their relationship.
CBS Board of Directors settles a 2016 lawsuit accusing the board of improperly compensating an incapacitated Redstone as early as 2014.
Redstone dies at the age of 97.
John Reed: Reed is named CEO of Citicorp.
Reed testifies before the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations of the Committee on Governmental Affairs regarding money laundering.
Retires as co-chairman and co-chief executive of Citigroup Inc.
New York Stock Exchange Chairman Richard Grasso resigns over criticism of his compensation package.
Reed is named interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange.
Testifies before the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs regarding the financial crisis.
Is elected president of the board of Boston Athenaem, an independent library and museum.
Harry Reid: US Representative from Nevada's 1st District.
Wins election to the US Senate.
Wins a second term in the Senate.
Re-elected to the Senate.
Democratic Party Whip in the Senate.
Re-elected to the Senate.
In the book, "Game Change," a quote from Reid about Barack Obama during the 2008 presidential election stirs racial controversy for which Reid apologizes.
Reid, for the second time, votes incorrectly for the health care reconciliation bill. He is in support of the bill but when he was asked to place his vote, he accidentally yells "no."
Is re-elected to the Senate.
Senate Minority Leader.
Breaks several ribs and bones in his face when a piece of exercise equipment he is using breaks, causing him to fall.
Announces he will not seek re-election.

Reid files a lawsuit in a Nevada court against Thera-Band's parent company, the Hygenic Corp, along with Hygenic Intangible Property Holding Co. and Performance Health LLC. Reid claims that Thera-Band's exercise equipment malfunctioned, causing him serious injuries.
Reid files an amended complaint in his civil case against Thera-Band and its parent companies.
Reid delivers his final speech as Senate Minority Leader and US Senator from Nevada.
Announced as UNLV Boyd School of Law's first distinguished fellow in law and policy.

Undergoes surgery at Johns Hopkins Cancer Center for pancreatic cancer. According to a statement from Reid's family: "His doctors caught the problem early during a routine screening and his surgeons are confident that the surgery was a success and that the prognosis for his recovery is good. He will undergo chemotherapy as the next step in his treatment."
Reid calls for an end to the legislative filibuster in a New York Times opinion piece, asserting that removing the procedure would help end the "era of obstruction and inaction" in the Senate.
Richard Reid: Travels to Brussels, Belgium. While there, Reid tells Belgian authorities he's lost his British passport and is issued a new one by the British Embassy.
Buys a round-trip ticket from Paris to Miami to Antigua.

Is questioned by airport officials after a security agent becomes suspicious because Reid had paid for his ticket with cash and is traveling without checking luggage. By the time Reid is cleared to board his flight, the plane has already left Paris.

Boards American Airlines Flight 63, Paris to Miami. During the flight, Reid tries to use a match to light explosives hidden in his shoes. Passengers and crew restrain him. The flight diverts to Boston. Reid is arrested.
Is indicted on nine counts, including attempted use of a weapon of mass destruction, attempted murder of passengers on an aircraft, and attempted homicide of US nationals overseas.
Pleads not guilty to eight charges. His attorney asks the court to dismiss the ninth count, attempted wrecking of a mass transportation vehicle, which is dismissed.
Pleads guilty to the eight counts against him.
Is sentenced to life in prison and fined $2 million.

Saajid Mohammed Badat, of the United Kingdom, is charged with conspiring with and aiding Reid. The British indictment alleges that Badat and Reid obtained custom-made shoe bombs in Afghanistan to be used to attack US interests.
Badat pleads guilty to conspiring with Reid to blow up a US aircraft.
Badat is sentenced to 13 years in prison. There is evidence that he had withdrawn from the plot.
Carl Reiner: Reiner makes his Broadway acting debut in a patriotic musical, "Inside U.S.A."
Wins the Emmy for Best Supporting Performance by an Actor for "Caesar's Hour."
Wins the Emmy for Best Continuing Supporting Performance by an Actor in Drama or Comedy for "Caesar's Hour."

"The Dick Van Dyke Show" debuts on CBS. The series was originally going to be titled "Head of the Family," with Reiner starring as Rob Petrie. After a pilot was shot, the show was reworked with a new cast, led by Van Dyke and Mary Tyler Moore, and a new title. Reiner appears as Alan Brady, a bombastic variety show host.
Wins the Emmy for Outstanding Writing Achievement in Comedy for "The Dick Van Dyke Show."
Wins two Emmy Awards for Outstanding Comedy Series and Outstanding Writing Achievement in Comedy for "The Dick Van Dyke Show."
Wins two Emmy Awards for Outstanding Comedy Series and Outstanding Writing Achievement in Comedy or Variety for "The Dick Van Dyke Show."
Wins Emmy for Outstanding Program Achievements in Entertainment for "The Dick Van Dyke Show."
Wins Emmy for Outstanding Comedy Series for "The Dick Van Dyke Show."
The final episode of "The Dick Van Dyke Show" airs. In the series finale, Rob Petrie (Van Dyke) writes a memoir and Alan Brady (Reiner) agrees to turn it into a sitcom.

"The Jerk" debuts. Standup comic-turned-actor Steve Martin stars as a Thermos-toting simpleton who gets rich inventing a nose guard for eyeglasses. Reiner and Martin collaborate on three more films, "All of Me," "Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid" and "The Man with Two Brains."
Wins an Emmy for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series for "Mad About You."
Reiner and Mel Brooks win a Grammy for "The 2000 Year Old Man in the Year 2000" in the Best Spoken Comedy Album category.
Is celebrated as an inductee to the Television Academy Hall of Fame.
